MissionCommands.Message: Welcome to the Reaction Control System tutorial, {{profileName}}.
In this lesson we will take a look at the various systems of the Mercury Capsule that helps stabilize it as well as change its attitude relative to Earth.

The Mercury Space Capsule comes equipped with a few systems to keep it stable and control its attitude. To do this, it needs to know where Earth's horizon is. Two mechanical components called the Horizon Scanners detect this.

Earth emits a lot of radiation; space does not. These scanners detect where a sudden drop in radiation happens - when the scanner goes from the threshold between Earth and space. One Horizon Scanner is used for Pitch and another for Roll.
These operate periodically, so if you see sudden change in pitch and roll this is the reason.

The Capsule comes with three gyroscopes that track the attitude and three accelerometers for rate indication. These can be slaved to the horizon scanner to get relative data to the Earths horizon. This is how the capsule knows its orientation in space.

The Pitch Horizon Scanner can only look forward with a field of view of +/-35 degrees. Same with roll, but it looks to the side. If you are outside of the horizon scanner's field of view, the gyros will revert to free mode.

When the GYROs are in free mode, the attitude will change based on thruster changes. Over time this can introduce an error in attitude. When the horizon is detected, they will snap back in slave mode and you will see a jump in the attitude indicators.

To automatically control the spacecraft in various situations, a system called the Automatic Stabilization Control System (ASCS) is used. In this mode, the spacecraft should be able to orient itself, and keep a given attitude based on the spacecraft's phase in the mission.

To maintain or change the attitude, the spacecraft uses a set of thrusters called the Reaction Control System (RCS). This system can be controlled by the Automatic Stabilization Control System (ASCS), a backup Rate Stabilization Control System (RSCS), or by manual propulsion (MP).

The Reaction Control System (RCS) consists of 18 thrusters that can alter the spacecraft's orientation. These are the thrusters that are used to change pitch, roll, yaw, or modify the capsules angular rates.

The capsule can be oriented and controlled by either an automatic mode using Automatic Stabilization Control System (ASCS), or by one of three astronaut-controlled modes: fly-by-wire, manual propulsion, and Rate Stabilization Control System. Let's first focus on the Automatic Stabilization Control System, then return to the other modes later.

The Automatic Stabilization Control System (ASCS) establishes and maintains a stable attitude using one of four basic automatic modes: Damper, Orientation, Attitude Hold, and Reentry. Let's first get familiar with the controls.

In the Virtual Cockpit, press [F6] to move the camera to the stabilization control panel. A rectangle called ASCS MODE SELECT with 3 switches configures this system in conjunction with 4 pull handles: a black MANUAL pull handle, and 3 white handles for PITCH, ROLL and YAW.

Currently, the system is configured to use the Automatic Stabilization Control System (ASCS) to control the spacecraft fully automatically. This means that it will slave the gyros to the horizon scanners and use the automatic Reaction Control System (RCS) system to orient and maintain the spacecraft in retro attitude.
Two switches and one handle are used to enable full automatic control. First of all, the ASCS MODE must be set to NORM.
And the middle AUTO switch must be set to AUTO.
Lastly, the black MANUAL handle must be in the IN position - like it currently is, unless you messed around.

In this mode, the automatic phase shifter system decides the orientation. This system is what rotates the spacecraft 180 degrees in YAW after capsule separation, automatically orients the spacecraft after rotation, maintains orientation, and rolls the spacecraft before reentry.

There are two Reaction Control System (RCS) control systems. One for automatic control called System A, and one for manual control called System B. The Automatic Stabilization Control System (ASCS) MODE we just talked about uses AUTO RCS system A. The middle AUTO switch decides which RCS system to use.

System A uses two thruster settings: low and high, and consists of 12 thrusters. System B has variable thruster strength based on how far you push the stick, called proportional control, and consists of 8 thrusters.

Each of the Reaction Control System (RCS) systems has its own fuel tank as indicated on the CONTROL FUEL gauge. The left gauge shows fuel available for AUTO and the right gauge shows fuel available for MANUAL. A low fuel warning light will be visible if one of the tanks is below 25%.

If the Automatic Stabilization Control System (ASCS) fails or you need to manually take control of the automatic Reaction Control System (RCS) system, you can use the Fly-By-Wire (FBW) mode. This enables you to use your stick to control the attitude.
In this mode, you can either fire the low thrusts or high thrusts depending on how far you push the stick. Using the keyboard, you can only fire the low thrusts manually. Let's try this mode.
The Fly-By-Wire (FBW) control mode is configured using the same two switches and the same handle, with one exception.
Since we are already in ASCS AUTO mode, all we need to do to set the ASCS MODE switch to FLY BY WIRE.

Use [W] and [S] to change attitude. Notice that you are burning fuel from the automatic Reaction Control System (RCS) system. Remember to use small thrusts. You have very limited fuel. If you have time, it's better to use a small thrust and a slow rate to get to your desired orientation.
You can enable auxiliary damping to automatically damp out any attitude rates down to 0.5 degrees/second. If you want the spacecraft to stand still, select this mode.

Let's try this now. Using Fly-By-Wire (FBW) mode, establish a pitch rate of +/- 3 degrees/second. This can be achieved using [W] or [S] and by monitoring the pitch rate indicator. Each dot is approx. 1 degree/sec. Thrust so the pitch rate needle is at the 3rd dot. Press ROGER when done.
With the rate at 3 degrees/second, set the ASCS-AUTO switch to AUX ON.
The rates should now damp to 0.5 deg/sec.

If you want to go to the fully Manual Propulsion (MP) system, first set the ASCS to NORM. Setting this switch to NORM or AUX does not really influence Manual Propulsion, so it can be set to either. But for now, use NORM.
Then set the middle AUTO switch to RATE COMD.
Lastly, pull the black MANUAL handle out.

In this mode, you will be able to thrust manually in all directions. This system is available even if the electrical system should fail. Try to change the attitude a bit using [W][S] for pitch, [A][D] for yaw, and [Q][E] for roll.
So far, we have looked at the fully automatic mode, the Fly-By-Wire (FBW) mode and the manual mode. Let's take a look at the last mode: Rate Stabilization Control System (RSCS)

The Rate Stabilization Control System (RSCS) is a semi-automatic mode that enables you to change attitude using the stick. But if the stick is centered, it will stop any rate momentum down to 3 degrees/second.
To enter Rate Stabilization Control System (RSCS) mode, first set the MODE switch to NORM. This should already be the case.
Then set the middle AUTO switch to RATE COMD. This enables Reaction Control System (RCS) System B.
Lastly, push the black MANUAL handle in.

Use [W] and [S] to change attitude. Notice you are burning fuel from the manual Reaction Control System (RCS) system B. In this mode, the angular rates are reduced to 3 deg/sec when you don't give any input. The RSCS will also limit your maximum angular rate to 10 deg/sec.

This means that you need to hold stick deflection in the direction you wish to change attitude. The rates will build up to 10 deg/sec and then stop firing the thrusters. At this point the capsule will rotate in the direction of the deflection. When you are at the desired attitude, release the stick. The RSCS will damp the rates down to 3 deg/sec. Damp the rest yourself.

Give this a try now. Deflect the stick to pitch upwards and keep the deflection in (press and hold [S]). Monitor that the pitch rate builds up to 10 deg/sec and maintains that. Then release and verify rates are reduced to about 3 deg/sec. Press ROGER when complete.
Use this mode to manually orient the craft so the attitude is 0 yaw, 0 roll and 0 pitch. Press ROGER when complete.
Great - let's go back to full Automatic Stabilization Control System (ASCS) mode. The ASCS MODE switch is already at NORM.
Set the middle AUTO switch to AUTO.

One last thing I want to mention is the ability to combine the manual modes and the Automatic Stabilization Control System (ASCS) mode. To do this, you still need the MODE switch in the NORM position and the AUTO switch in AUTO position.
In this configuration, pull the MANUAL handle OUT.

The capsule will still be in fully automatic mode, but if you pull out any of the PITCH, YAW, and/or ROLL handles, that select axis will be in manual mode. This is good for letting the Automatic Stabilization Control System (ASCS) control one or two axes while manually controlling the other(s).
Pull the PITCH handle now.

Try to maneuver the craft in Roll, Pitch and Yaw. Notice that the ASCS mode controls Yaw and Roll, so your input is ignored on these axes while you are in control of the pitch. This consumes fuel from both tanks. System A handles yaw and roll, while System B handles pitch.
There are more configurations available but these are the ones you really need to understand. The others are something you can get creative about after learning the basics.

To sum up: Automatic Stabilization Control System (ASCS) is the autopilot. Attitude is defined by GYROS and Horizon Scanners. Reaction Control System (RCS) is the system that fires thrusters - it's made up from two systems A and B. A is automatic, B is manual.
The Reaction Control System (RCS) is controlled by the autopilot, or manually by Fly-By-Wire (FBW), Rate Stabilization Control System (RSCS) or Manual Propulsion (MP).

I know this was quite a lot, but it's important to understand how to control the capsule. I would recommend checking the Reaction Control System (RCS) chapter in the Mercury Flight Manual too, and try this lesson again after reading the flight modes chapter.
Anyways, good job, that's it for now.

Title: Tutorial 5 - Attitude Control
Description: The Reaction Control System (RCS) makes it possible for the spacecraft to change its orientation in space. In this lesson you will learn how to use the RCS in both auto and manual mode.
BriefingText:
BRIEFING

The Reaction Control System consists of 16 thrusters in two systems that will allow you to change the attitude/orientation on the spacecraft. Two independent systems are available for use: the AUTO system and the MANUAL system. Each has its own thrusters and fuel tanks.
